message.content:
Step 1. Calculate the Current Ratio  
• Total Current Assets (end) = 9,717,259.46  
• Total Current Liabilities (end) = 1,493,246.99  
• Current Ratio = 9,717,259.46 / 1,493,246.99 ≈ 6.51  

Step 2. Calculate the Quick Ratio  
• For the Quick Ratio, exclude Inventory from current assets.  
• Inventory = 450,000.00  
• Quick Assets = Total Current Assets – Inventory = 9,717,259.46 – 450,000.00 = 9,267,259.46  
• Quick Ratio = 9,267,259.46 / 1,493,246.99 ≈ 6.21  

Step 3. Calculate the Debt to Asset Ratio  
• Total Assets (end) = 15,200,446.16  
• Total Liabilities = Total Assets – Owner’s Equity = 15,200,446.16 – 13,707,199.17 = 1,493,246.99  
• Debt to Asset Ratio = Total Liabilities / Total Assets = 1,493,246.99 / 15,200,446.16 ≈ 0.0983, or about 0.10  

Step 4. Calculate the Debt to Equity Ratio  
• Debt to Equity Ratio = Total Liabilities / Owner’s Equity = 1,493,246.99 / 13,707,199.17 ≈ 0.1089, or about 0.11  

Step 5. Calculate the Cash Flow to Debt Ratio  
• From the cash flow statement, Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities = –64,099.10  
• Total Debt (liabilities) = 1,493,246.99  
• Cash Flow to Debt Ratio = –64,099.10 / 1,493,246.99 ≈ –0.0429, or about –0.04  

Thus, the answer in JSON format is:
------------------------------------------------------------
{
  "solution": {
    "Current Ratio": "6.51",
    "Quick Ratio": "6.21",
    "Debt to Asset Ratio": "0.10",
    "Debt to Equity Ratio": "0.11",
    "Cash Flow to Debt Ratio": "-0.04"
  }
}
